content.raw:
Sweet! Simpler sounds better.

Also, sorry for misunderstanding on defaulting to `@attached_to` vs `@relative_to`; however, in my mind it yields the same class of problem \(making the default context more complex / possibly less useful, and possibly harder to go from the existing behavior\).
content.html:
Sweet! Simpler sounds better.

Also, sorry for misunderstanding on defaulting to @attached_to vs @relative_to; however, in my mind it yields the same class of problem (making the default context more complex / possibly less useful, and possibly harder to go from the existing behavior).

content.raw:
Defaulting to the parent xml element is probably more straight forward so I'm okay with going with that. 

In terms of adhering to the spec, I think making the a Frame Pose's default `resolveTo` be the same as it's default `relative_to` adheres better to the spec. For a Frame's Pose, the default `relative_to` value (not the `relative_to` attribute) is the Frame's `@attached_to` even if the Pose has it's `@relative_to` attribute set. So when calling resolve without a `resolveTo`, on a frame's pose, it would resolve relative to the attached-to frame, If the Frame's `@attached_to` is empty, the pose will resolve to the model/world frame. This lines up with how a joint's default `resolveTo` is the child link frame because the joint frame is attached to the child link. Like I said, this is convoluted, so let's go with the parent xml element.
content.html:
Defaulting to the parent xml element is probably more straight forward so I'm okay with going with that.

In terms of adhering to the spec, I think making the a Frame Pose's default resolveTo be the same as it's default relative_to adheres better to the spec. For a Frame's Pose, the default relative_to value (not the relative_to attribute) is the Frame's @attached_to even if the Pose has it's @relative_to attribute set. So when calling resolve without a resolveTo, on a frame's pose, it would resolve relative to the attached-to frame, If the Frame's @attached_to is empty, the pose will resolve to the model/world frame. This lines up with how a joint's default resolveTo is the child link frame because the joint frame is attached to the child link. Like I said, this is convoluted, so let's go with the parent xml element.

content.raw:
To clarify, I thought @azeey was suggesting that the frame's default `resolveTo` should be its `@attached_to` attribute value, which would default to the parent xml element if unset, which is different than defaulting to `@relative_to`

but I still lean towards default resolve to parent XML element
content.html:
To clarify, I thought @azeey was suggesting that the frame's default resolveTo should be its @attached_to attribute value, which would default to the parent xml element if unset, which is different than defaulting to @relative_to

but I still lean towards default resolve to parent XML element

content.raw:
I agree with Steve - `resolveTo` should by default resolve to the parent XML element. We perhaps did not capture this explicitly, but I think the default behavior should reflect the current behavior that is reflected in the current kinematics tutorials:

[http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec\_model\_kinematics&cat=specification&](http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_model_kinematics&cat=specification&)

If I understand this fully, if `resolveTo`'s target frame were to resolve by default to `@relative_to`, then we’re really just encoding the same behavior as the deprecated `Pose()` / the new `RawPose()` functionality, which I think would hurt in terms of adhering to the specification.  \(`libsdformat`s default behavior should encourage sticking to the specification as much as possible.\)
content.html:
I agree with Steve - resolveTo should by default resolve to the parent XML element. We perhaps did not capture this explicitly, but I think the default behavior should reflect the current behavior that is reflected in the current kinematics tutorials:

http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=spec_model_kinematics&cat=specification&

If I understand this fully, if resolveTo's target frame were to resolve by default to @relative_to, then we’re really just encoding the same behavior as the deprecated Pose() / the new RawPose() functionality, which I think would hurt in terms of adhering to the specification. (libsdformats default behavior should encourage sticking to the specification as much as possible.)

content.raw: No, I don't think we discussed this in the proposal. My reasoning is that the default resolveTo behaves similar to the default relative_to. For elements that existed in sdformat 1.6, the default relative_to is the parent xml element except for joint. For Frames in 1.7, we have a more nuanced default relative_to and I thought the default resolveTo should mirror that.
content.html: No, I don't think we discussed this in the proposal. My reasoning is that the default resolveTo behaves similar to the default relative_to. For elements that existed in sdformat 1.6, the default relative_to is the parent xml element except for joint. For Frames in 1.7, we have a more nuanced default relative_to and I thought the default resolveTo should mirror that.

content.raw: yeah, there's a lot missing from the DOM API
content.html: yeah, there's a lot missing from the DOM API

content.raw: it was just expedient; that test was using the world_complete.sdf file, so I just added a bit to it. the model-based tests are much more complete than the world-based tests
content.html: it was just expedient; that test was using the world_complete.sdf file, so I just added a bit to it. the model-based tests are much more complete than the world-based tests

content.raw:
I've understood the default resolveTo to be based on the sdf 1.6 pose tree. Aside from frames, the default resolveTo is always the xml parent name (`__model__` for  link, parent link name for collisions, etc). For joints, it's the child link name. I had assumed that a frame in a model would be like a link, with a default resolveTo of `__model__`, and `world` for `//world/frame`, which is what the `graphSourceName` corresponds to.

Did we discuss this in the proposal somewhere? I'm open to this suggestion, but it goes counter to my prior assumptions.
content.html:
I've understood the default resolveTo to be based on the sdf 1.6 pose tree. Aside from frames, the default resolveTo is always the xml parent name (__model__ for link, parent link name for collisions, etc). For joints, it's the child link name. I had assumed that a frame in a model would be like a link, with a default resolveTo of __model__, and world for //world/frame, which is what the graphSourceName corresponds to.

Did we discuss this in the proposal somewhere? I'm open to this suggestion, but it goes counter to my prior assumptions.

content.raw: Yeah, saw those after I made the comment. They seem out of place, but that's okay for now.
content.html: Yeah, saw those after I made the comment. They seem out of place, but that's okay for now.

content.raw: there's some in the light_dom test

content.raw: It would be nice to add some tests where `//model/pose` are resolved relative to other frames.

content.raw: Shouldn't the default resolveTo of a frame be the frame it's attached to?
content.html: Shouldn't the default resolveTo of a frame be the frame it's attached to?

content.raw: Interesting, it looks like that's not in the SDF DOM API yet
content.html: Interesting, it looks like that's not in the SDF DOM API yet

content.raw: Do we not support Joint sensors?
